Award.AwardTitle: Lipid Network Flux Cartography for Quantitative Control of Oil Accumulation and Composition

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Plant oils are a vital part of human life and are utilized as food, chemicals, and fuels. It is predicted that world output of plant oils must double by 2040 to meet the needs of the growing human population, and even larger increases are needed if plant oils will be used to increasingly replace petroleum as fuels and chemicals. To meet this rising demand we need a better understanding of the metabolic reactions that control plant oil biosynthesis and oil composition. The goal of this project is to quantitatively describe the control exerted by key oil and membrane lipid biosynthetic proteins over the flux of vital intermediates into either oils or membrane lipids in the model plant, Arabidopsis. To prepare the next generation workforce the PIs will incorporate their research into training of undergraduate and graduate students and a post-doctoral fellow. Since plant oils are valuable renewable resources used for food, fuels, and chemicals this research will further our ability to guide plant lipid metabolic networks for the production of designer oils.

Little is known about what controls the flux of de novo diacylglycerol into alternative branches of the lipid biosynthetic network in different plant species. The PIs hypothesize that a crucial control point is the partitioning of de novo synthesized diacylglycerol between phosphatidylcholine and triacylglycerol synthesis. The aims of the research are: 1) deciphering the roles of the non-redundant diglyceride acetyltransferase 1 and diglyceride acetyltransferase 2 triacylglycerol synthesizing enzymes in partitioning of de novo diacylglycerol between direct oil production and membrane lipid synthesis; 2) characterize the role of phosphatidylcholine synthesis enzymes in partitioning of de novo diacylglycerol into different branches of the lipid biosynthetic network; 3) develop quantitative kinetic models for the control of glycerolipid fluxes in Arabidopsis; and 4) explore protein:protein interactions to characterize the molecular components that make up the lipid metabolic complexes that control diacylglycerol fluxes. The above approaches will be combined with computer modeling to produce a quantitative description of the control of metabolite fluxes through the plant lipid metabolic network that can then guide the production of designer plant oils.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Plant lipids comprise both essential membrane lipids required for growth, and valuable plant products such as vegetable oils. Plant oils are a vital part of human life and are utilized as food, feed, chemicals (plastics, paints, lubricants, cosmetics, etc.), and biofuels. World production of this valuable renewable resource is over 100 billion kg plant oil per year and is worth over $120 billion. It is predicted that world output of plant oils must double by 2040 to meet the needs of the growing human population, and even larger increases are needed if plant oils will be used to increasingly replace petroleum for production of fuels and chemicals. The sequences of hundreds or thousands of oil biosynthetic genes are known, yet little is known about how these genes controls the partitioning of fatty acids for production and maintenance of essential membrane lipids versus the accumulation of valuable storage oils with fatty acid composition optimized for different uses. The goals of this work were to identify how various plant genes differentially affect membrane lipid and oil biosynthesis, which could be valuable for breeding or bioengineering ‘designer oil’ plants to meet the needs of the human population. This research led to the production of ten peer-reviewed scientific publications, one book chapter, and supported the training of two postdoctoral researchers, three graduate students, and 15 undergraduate research assistants.

Plant metabolism is typically portrayed as a highly interconnected network of chemical reactions controlled by metabolic enzymes. However, the basic knowledge provided by identification of all the genes that are suspected to produce this enzyme network is insufficient to control the flux of substrates into the products of choice. We have combined the isotopic tracing of carbon flux through metabolic pathways, with in vivo analysis of protein-protein interactions, and with analysis of genetic mutants and bioengineering plant lines, to better understand how various lipid biosynthetic genes affect both membrane lipid homeostasis and vegetable oil production. A major outcome of this research is the expansion of the network model for plant lipid metabolism to include different lipid biosynthetic metabolons working on distinct pools of the same substrate. Previously intermediates of at branchpoints of metabolic pathways have been thought to be available to various different types of enzymatic reactions. However, the isotopic tracing has indicated that several key intermediates of plant lipid metabolism (e.g. diacylglycerol, phosphatidylcholine) are not available to all possible enzymes that may use them as a substrate at the same time. Instead there are distinct pools of the same metabolite involved in different aspects of lipid metabolism, each of which is utilized by different types of lipid biosynthetic enzymes, leading to different lipid products in leaves and seeds. We have also identified which of several different oil biosynthetic enzymes work on which distinct substrate pools, and lead to production of oils with different fatty acid compositions. This expansion of the network model helps to explain the limited successes of some previous plant lipid engineering approaches, because the engineered enzymes may not have had access to the substrates required for the reaction as previously thought. In addition, our results have identified gene products which affect the flux of newly synthesized fatty acids into membrane lipids or oils in both seeds and leaves, as well as identifying gene products that can be used for bioengineering the accumulation of valuable unusual fatty acids utilized by the chemical industry. These results can be used to formulate new plant oil engineering strategies that may provide alternative sources of nutritionally valuable food oils, or chemically reactive lipids that can functionally replace petroleum for production of industrial chemicals. This knowledge will allow for the development of new value-added crops that can reinvigorate low income rural farming communities, reduce the environmental impact of petroleum consumption, and enhance national security via creation of renewable, domestically-produced chemical feedstocks.
